event.title: the first several decades of the 19th century, the village grew

data.event: In the first several decades of the 19th century, the village grew quickly as a hub for commerce being carried on the Little Juniata River and on the nearby Pennsylvania Canal.
By 1850, the Pennsylvania Railroad had passed through the valley.
In 1853, the Mountain Female Seminary opened in Birmingham as a boarding school for girls.
In its earliest years, the school benefited from the ease of transportation afforded by the passage of the Pennsylvania railroad through Birmingham.
